AdeelZubair,"2016-07-01T12:03:15.787Z","A Faithful Tribute","

This is a follow up to the very successful 5002812 &ndash
column3: Classic Pirate Minifigure from 2015. It was no surprised that LEGO was going to continue this rather special trend of celebrating classic themes through these exclusive promos.

column1: This set is a direct homage and tribute to 6012 - Siege Cart
column2: a small impulse LEGO Castle set released exactly 30 years ago. Unintentionally this promo becomes even more special as it&rsquo
column3: s released a few weeks after the passing of Daniel August Krentz, a retired LEGO designer who worked at LEGO between mid-1970s until 2000. Daniel is known to many us as the designer of 375 &ndash

column1: The primary aspect of the box design is very reminiscent of most of the boxes between 1960 &ndash
column3: the white studs covering the entire box and the LEGO logo in the top left. The box doesn&rsquo
column4: t scream attention to the contents much like the current products do, instead they show a small and simple vignette of the set with an extract of the booklet included and the 2016 stamp. Other nice details of the packaging include the LEGO System logo from 1950s on three sides. To open the box, you have to slide open the drawer on the right hand side which contains the pieces and booklet.

column1: Not only does the contents of the product reflect the classic sets, it&rsquo
column2: s also presented through the packaging and experience as you open the box which is one of the many reasons why this series is clearly a success. These easily have the best packaging of any LEGO product alongside Architecture, LEGO Ideas and the two exclusive Technic sets (41999 &amp

column1: The booklet starts off with the simple instructions to build the Minifigure and model. It follows up by documenting the classic LEGO Castle sets through a timeline starting with the origins leading up to 2016&rsquo
column2: s Nexo Knights. Which follows a similar pattern with the previous two promos in this series. With the future instalments I can only guess it will be a similar scenario by promoting a new theme / sub-theme that links back to a classic LEGO theme.

column1: Surprisingly this also comes with a sticker sheet / postcard
column2: the stickers are images of Minifigures represented throughout the Castle themes as well as the two LEGO logos. On the reverse side it&rsquo
column3: s a typical postcard design with a &lsquo
column5: twist! I wish it was just a postcard with an awesome print showcasing this set instead of the stickers which slightly decreases the exclusivity of&nbsp

column1: The Minifigure is a near replica of the official castle sets, the difference being the weapon of choice
column2: the long axe is a rather odd choice, perhaps an alternative weapon such as a bow and quiver could have been included instead. The printing is fantastic, both on the torso and the shield. I really appreciate that the torso or printing wasn&rsquo
column7: s was one aspect that took away from previous promo (5003082 - Classic Pirate Minifigure.)

column1: The only noticeable difference between this model and the one included with 6012 - Siege Cart is the use of brown slopes over plates for the front bow shape, my guess is they weren&rsquo
column2: t available in the 80s. Besides that, pretty much every detail and feature from the original model has been replicated into this model, including the shield attachment at the front!&nbsp
column4: ve stayed faithful and not over done the details to bring the design into modern day.

column1: Comparing this promo to the previous two
column3: s easily the superior of the three! Not only does it reflect and celebrate the classic castle theme it also gives a faithful reproduction to a classic set: 6012 - Siege Cart
column4: rather than including a random assembly of parts as did &lsquo
column6: s a perfect example of what a faithful homage and promotional product should be!

,TRUE,5,5,4,5,5 Ladondorf","2016-07-07T04:27:11.6Z","Missing Piece!","

I got this set on my birthday yesterday along with the latest version of the
column3: Falcon. It comes free with any large purchase directly from LEGO by VIPs. Unfortunately, my copy came with an error which is a shame coming from an exclusive set such as this.

column1: The box is made from a higher quality material than your standard LEGO box. It'
column2: s print pays homage to classic LEGO boxes from the 60&#39
column3: s. It even comes with the 1958&nbsp
column5: of the LEGO logo. This set is noteworthy as its contents are accessed by sliding out a little tray within the main box. On the back is a picture of a knight from the 2013 Castle theme.&nbsp
column6: Inside are the bag of parts, the instruction booklet and even a sticker sheet containing stickers of various knight minifigures&nbsp
column7: from across the years along with two versions of the LEGO logo. The other side of the sticker sheet appears to be a post card. The instruction booklet, I believe, is&nbsp
column8: also of higher quality than the standard. The pages that come after the instructions themselves display the evolution of LEGO Castle.

column3: theme, most of the parts are pretty basic pieces that have been in production for a long time. The ones that stand out the most are the dark brown spears and the slope pieces used for the front as they are newer pieces. The main reason to get this set, however, are the knight&#39
column4: s torso and the two shields. They each come with the classic Lion Knights print first seen in 1984. It&#39
column5: s a bit of a shame that the brown and grey colored&nbsp
column7: with the set have to be molded in their new counterparts which slightly detracts from the classic feel. As stated earlier, my copy of this set came with a missing piece or rather the wrong piece. The set is supposed to come with two brown slope pieces for the front of the cart when mine came with one brown curved 4x1&nbsp
column8: slope and an extra 1x3 black slope. It&#39
column9: s sad to see an error like this. That slope brick was a major part of the model aesthetically&nbsp
column11: m not entirely sure I have an extra one in my&nbsp
column12: collection. On the other hand, though,&nbsp
column13: I guess it makes my copy even more exclusive.

column1: The set comes with one classic Lion Knight. He'
column2: s a great addition to the collection for people didn&#39
column3: t have a chance to pick these old castle sets up when they were still in stores. Even people who own the originals will appreciate a classic knight figure&nbsp
column4: in brand new condition. He comes with a dark grey axe&nbsp
column5: as an accessory. I find it odd that the knight&#39
column7: in light gray rather than dark gray, which was the color used for the original Lion Knight figures. The front of the box along with some promotional art even suggests otherwise.

column1: Building the set is very easy as the model
column2: based on older LEGO sets which tended to be very simple.

column1: The model is actually a homage to set 6012 Siege Cart. It remains incredibly faithful to the original with the only differences between the two builds being the differently colored brown and grey pieces, the use of dark brown for the spears rather than old brown or even reddish brown, the redesigned front of the cart and the minifigures. The original set included two while this set only includes one. The knight in this set, as previously stated, comes with a light grey helmet and an axe while the equivalent figure from the old set came with a dark grey helmet along with a quiver and a bow and arrow.
Very nice little set. I like the idea of these little promotional sets that pay homage to classic LEGO themes. I wonder what the 2017 set will be if they'
column2: ll even make one. Perhaps it&#39
column4: be based on the original town theme as that&#39
column5: s the only classic theme that hasn&#39
column6: t had a dedicated promotional set, although that wouldn&#39
column7: t be very exiting. Out of the three existing sets, I highly recommend&nbsp
column10: s the largest. It also has mostly period accurate pieces, especially on the minifigure, which is something I can&#39
column11: t say about the classic Space or Pirates set. The latter, in particular, being extremely disappointing with no attempt at recreating anything from the original Pirates line. I actually became a LEGO VIP just to get this set. I recommend doing so for yourself, as well. It&#39
column12: s absolutely free and as a result, you get cool stuff like this. I&#39
column13: m still disappointed about the missing piece, though.

column1: ,TRUE,5,4,4,5,5 Odeinoichus","2017-08-25T15:10:56.397Z","A Brilliant Love Letter to Classic Castle Era","
column13: > This little freebie was given out last year in the summer and it&rsquo
column15: ve managed to get to the LEGO store to pick one up. It&rsquo
column16: s a huge throwback to classic Castle and features a very nice looking model and a vintage knight from the Crusaders. This is a great freebie item and this review will explain why.

column8: >Box: The box is a very sturdy bit of cardboard stock with a slide out tray, inside rests the instruction manual, a sticker sheet and the parts in a plastic bag. The design evokes classic system LEGO boxes and I love the throwback to my youth, it makes the set highly collectible because of the box alone.

>The stickers are part of a thick postcard style item that showcases numerous vintage era Castle Minifigures as stickers, the eras represented include the original 1978 Castle, the 1986 Crusader Lion, a 1988 Black Knight, 1993&rsquo
column9: s Dragon Knight, a Fright Knight from 1997, an Evil Knight from 2006&rsquo
column12: m not mistaken the Kingdoms Lion Knight from 2010 and Clay from last year&rsquo
column14: s a fairly nice addition for younger builders.

column8: >Instructions: A very nice looking manual here, with all the pages for the build and the parts list and then a historical look at LEGO Castle, first with images of sets from each era, or at least a set from each era and then a Minifigure through the ages style list with a representation of each era with one knight or other character. It&rsquo
column9: s a very fun looking manual design which stands out to me and looks great.

column8: >The parts in this set are all standard parts, nothing unique to stand out here. It&rsquo
column9: s not meant to be a parts pack for MOC enthusiasts, but a set celebrating the LEGO Castle theme from the first year it was released to 2016&rsquo
s his name. The print is re-captured from the original 1986 variant on the torso, the head and the shield. He&rsquo
column10: s a great looking Minifig and extremely desirable for fans of that era. I always preferred the LEGO Lion Crusaders over the plain Crusaders without the royal seal on the shield emblem.

column8: >The build for the model is fairly straight forward and easy to follow. This build is a complete re-release with new modern molded parts and colours of the original 6012 Siege Cart set from 1986. That model featured two Knights, an archer and a regular knight to man the cart. It&rsquo
column9: s really a great nostalgic build for older fans of LEGO Castle and I&rsquo
column10: d recommend sharing the build with your children, if you have children of course, to recapture the fun of the vintage Castle set.

column8: >I have very fond memories of LEGO Castle, it along with Pirates was one of my all-time favorite Themes of the 1980&rsquo
column9: s when I was a young builder. This little Siege Cart model was one I never owned before now and I can safely say that I love the sheer simplicity of the design.

column8: >There are no spring loaded projectiles, no overly-detailed stickers or complicated design choices to make it more realistic. Instead what&rsquo
column9: s there is what you would expect to see from LEGO System, and I may be biased, but I love this little model. The colours are different, but that&rsquo
column11: s fun and inspires imagination play with your LEGO Castle sets.

column9: re going to have to go to the secondary market to pick it up. This means you&rsquo
column10: re going to have to pay for it, a lot more than the cost needed to spend to get it for free from LEGO S&amp
column11: H back in July of last year. So I&rsquo
column12: d recommend this set strongly to folks if they&rsquo
column13: re willing to spend the money necessary to get it. Otherwise you may wish to skip it.

,TRUE,5,3,4,5,5 alfred_the_buttler","2019-03-30T19:38:53.077Z","Perfect throwback to Classic Castle ","

This set is for children from the 80&rsquo
column2: s. If you still have your Classic Castle sets, this will fit right in. Plus if you never owned any type of castle themed cart it will fill in that missing gap in your collection.&nbsp

column1: I picked this up on Bricklink for $6 which is a tremendous value, especially compared to what it would cost just to part out a Classic Castle set without the minifigures.

The packaging is beautiful and can easily be opened by slicing through a sticker without damaging the box. Included is a postcard with stickers of minifigures throughout the years and an instruction book on heavier stock than usual. The first half of the instructions are the instructions themselves, the second half is a history of castle sets and minifigures in picture form. In a way it reminds me of the catalogs that used to come with sets back in the 80&rsquo
column2: s, much more elaborate than the pictures of other sets in the back of instruction books today.&nbsp

column1: The set itself is pretty true to 6012 with an exception of some curved slope bricks that are much more visually appealing. The minifigures and shields are perfect, I&rsquo
column2: m sure before long I won&rsquo
column3: t even know which ones came with this set as opposed to being from my childhood collection.&nbsp

column1: I only own two castle sets, 6080 which of course is probably the greatest set ever, and
column2: 6041 which is nice little add on. While I&rsquo
column3: ve been able to expand my (much larger) Classic Space collection while keeping to a 10 cents per brick budget, I have not been able to do this with Castle sets, so I&rsquo
column4: m very glad to have picked this one up.&nbsp

column1: This set is like any small set from the 80&rsquo
column2: s, nothing too technical about it. On its own it doesn&rsquo
column3: t do much, but for a child of the 80&rsquo
